Class VehicleWorld

java.lang.Object
greenfoot.World
VehicleWorld
public class VehicleWorld extends greenfoot.World

The new and vastly improved 2022 Vehicle Simulation Assignment.

This is the first redo of the 8 year old project. Lanes are now drawn dynamically, allowing for much greater customization. Pedestrians can now move in two directions. The graphics are better and the interactions smoother.

The Pedestrians are not as dumb as before (they don't want straight into Vehicles) and the Vehicles do a somewhat better job detecting Pedestrians.

Version Notes - Feb 2023 --> Includes grid <--> lane conversion method --> Now starts with 1-way, 5 lane setup (easier) V2023_021 --> Improved Vehicle Repel (still work in progress) --> Implemented Z-sort, disabled paint order between Pedestrians and Vehicles (looks much better now) --> Implemented lane-based speed modifiers for max speed V2023_04 --> Repel has been re-imagined and now takes the sizes of Actors into consideration better, and also only moves Actors verically. (The code to move in both dimensions is there and works but it's commented out because this is the effect I was going for). --> TODO -- Improve flow to avoid Removed From World errors when a Vehicle calls super.act() and is removed there.

    • VehicleWorld

      public VehicleWorld()
      Constructor for objects of class MyWorld. Note that the Constrcutor for the default world is always called when you click the reset button in the Greenfoot scenario screen - this is is basically the code that runs when the program start. Anything that should be done FIRST should go here.

  • Method Details

    • act

      public void act()

      act in class greenfoot.World

    • getLaneY

      public int getLaneY(int lane)
      Given a lane number (zero-indexed), return the y position in the centre of the lane. (doesn't factor offset, so watch your offset, i.e. with Bus).
      Parameters:
      lane - the lane number (zero-indexed)
      Returns:
      int the y position of the lane's center, or -1 if invalid

    • getLane

      public int getLane(int y)
      Given a y-position, return the lane number (zero-indexed). Note that the y-position must be valid, and you should include the offset in your calculations before calling this method. For example, if a Bus is in a lane at y=100, but is offset by -20, it is actually in the lane located at y=80, so you should send 80 to this method, not 100.
      Parameters:
      y - - the y position of the lane the Vehicle is in
      Returns:
      int the lane number, zero-indexed

    • prepareLanes

      public static int[] prepareLanes(greenfoot.World world, greenfoot.GreenfootImage target, VehicleSpawner[] spawners, int startY, int heightPerLane, int lanes, int spacing, boolean twoWay, boolean centreSplit, int centreSpacing)

    • zSort

      public static void zSort(ArrayList<greenfoot.Actor> actorsToSort, greenfoot.World world)
      A z-sort method which will sort Actors so that Actors that are displayed "higher" on the screen (lower y values) will show up underneath Actors that are drawn "lower" on the screen (higher y values), creating a better perspective.

    • prepareLanes

      public static int[] prepareLanes(greenfoot.World world, greenfoot.GreenfootImage target, VehicleSpawner[] spawners, int startY, int heightPerLane, int lanes, int spacing, boolean twoWay, boolean centreSplit)

      The prepareLanes method is a static (standalone) method that takes a list of parameters about the desired roadway and then builds it.

      Note: So far, Centre-split is the only option, regardless of what values you send for that parameters.

      This method does three things:

      • Determines the Y coordinate for each lane (each lane is centered vertically around the position)
      • Draws lanes onto the GreenfootImage target that is passed in at the specified / calculated positions. (Nothing is returned, it just manipulates the object which affects the original).
      • Places the VehicleSpawners (passed in via the array parameter spawners) into the World (also passed in via parameters).

      After this method is run, there is a visual road as well as the objects needed to spawn Vehicles. Examine the table below for an in-depth description of what the roadway will look like and what each parameter/component represents.

                        <=== Start Y
  ||||||||||||||  <=== Top Border
  /------------\
  |            |  
  |      Y[0]  |  <=== Lane Position (Y) is the middle of the lane
  |            |
  \------------/
  [##] [##] [##| <== spacing ( where the lane lines or borders are )
  /------------\
  |            |  
  |      Y[1]  |
  |            |
  \------------/
  ||||||||||||||  <== Bottom Border
      Parameters:
      world - The World that the VehicleSpawners will be added to
      target - The GreenfootImage that the lanes will be drawn on, usually but not necessarily the background of the World.
      spawners - An array of VehicleSpawner to be added to the World
      startY - The top Y position where lanes (drawing) should start
      heightPerLane - The height of the desired lanes
      lanes - The total number of lanes desired
      spacing - The distance, in pixels, between each lane
      twoWay - Should traffic flow both ways? Leave false for a one-way street (Not Yet Implemented)
      centreSplit - Should the whole road be split in the middle? Or lots of parallel two-way streets? Must also be two-way street (twoWay == true) or else NO EFFECT
